item.description:

This article provides information about the book “Evolving the Alien: The Science of Extraterrestrial Life” by Jack Cohen and Ian Stewart. It covers various aspects of the book, including its publication details, synopsis, and reception.

Synopsis ðŸ”—

This section outlines the central argument of the book, which challenges the assumption that extraterrestrial life must resemble life on Earth or exist in Earth-like environments. Cohen and Stewart advocate for a broader perspective in the search for extraterrestrial life, suggesting that life forms could be radically different from what we know. The section introduces the concepts of “exobiology” versus “xenoscience” and “parochials” versus “universals” as key contrasts explored in the book. It also mentions the inclusion of science fiction references, including plot summaries of classic stories, to supplement the scientific content.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes critical responses to “Evolving the Alien.” The London Review of Books praised the book’s speculative approach for exposing conventional errors and its educational value regarding current scientific knowledge. However, it criticized the authors’ optimism about future space travel technology. Lawrence M. Krauss, in Nature, noted the book’s potential as a counterpoint to the “Rare Earth” hypothesis presented in Peter Ward and Donald Brownlee’s book.
